title: Athanasius I Gammolo
text:
Athanasius I Gammolo () was the <a href="Patriarch%20of%20Antioch">Patriarch of Antioch</a> and head of the <a href="Syriac%20Orthodox%20Church">Syriac Orthodox Church</a> from 594/595 or 603 until his death in 631. He is commemorated as a saint by the Syriac Orthodox Church in the "<a href="Martyrology%20of%20Rabban%20Sliba">Martyrology of Rabban Sliba</a>", and his feast day is <a href="3%20January">3 January</a>.
Biography.
Early life.
Athanasius was born into a wealthy family in the 6th century at <a href="Samsat">Samosata</a>, and was raised with his brother Severus under the care of their mother Joanna, after their father had died. According to Athanasius' biography of Patriarch <a href="Severus%20of%20Antioch">Severus of Antioch</a>, Athanasius' father had been a priest and friend of the patriarch, and his grandfather named Athanasius was also a priest and friend to the patriarch's grandfather Severus. The historicity of this assertion is doubtful, however, as Patriarch Severus' writings suggest he was a pagan convert from a pagan family, and thus it is likely this represents an attempt to Christianise his ancestry. Athanasius' mother donated most of her husband's money to the poor, but kept enough to provide for Athanasius and Severus. The two brothers received a good education, and later became monks at the Monastery of <a href="Qenneshre">Qenneshre</a>, where they were trained in the recitation of the Bible.
After the death of Patriarch <a href="Julian%20I%20%28Miaphysite%20patriarch%20of%20Antioch%29">Julian II</a>, a synod was held at a monastery near Qenneshre to elect his successor, and the bishops confined themselves, and fasted and prayed for three days. On the evening of the third day, it was revealed to the bishops that the monk that they would see passing by the monastery in the early morning of the next day was chosen by the <a href="Holy%20Spirit%20in%20Christianity">Holy Spirit</a> to be the next patriarch. The bishops saw Athanasius driving a camel by the monastery in the following morning, and after testing his knowledge and discovering he was a monk at Qenneshre, he was taken against his will and elected as patriarch. He agreed to become patriarch, but his assumption of the office was delayed for a year as the bishops agreed to his request that he be allowed to return to Qenneshre to complete his duty to bring salt from the salt mine at Gabbula to the monastery. This led him to become known as "Gammolo" ("camel driver" in Syriac). Sources disagree on the date of Athanasius' consecration as patriarch. It is placed on 6 November 603 by the "Chronicle" of <a href="Thomas%20the%20Presbyter">Thomas the Presbyter</a>, and is supported by <a href="Jacob%20of%20Edessa">Jacob of Edessa</a>, whereas <a href="Michael%20the%20Syrian">Michael the Syrian</a> dates the consecration to 594. It is likely that Michael or his source removed the vacancy between the death of Julian II and the consecration of Athanasius so to not cast doubt on the legitimacy of the patriarchal succession.
Patriarch of Antioch.
In 610 or 616/617, Athanasius and five bishops travelled to <a href="Alexandria">Alexandria</a> in Egypt after receiving a letter from the <a href="Coptic%20Orthodox%20Church">Coptic</a> <a href="Pope%20Anastasius%20of%20Alexandria">Pope Anastasius of Alexandria</a> written in the hope of restoring relations. The Syriac and Coptic churches, although both <a href="Non-Chalcedonian%20Christianity">non-Chalcedonian</a>, had been in schism as a consequence of the dispute over the issue of <a href="tritheism">tritheism</a> between Patriarch <a href="Peter%20III%20of%20Callinicum">Peter III</a> and <a href="Pope%20Damian%20of%20Alexandria">Pope Damian of Alexandria</a> in the late 6th century. Athanasius and his companions, including the bishops <a href="Paul%20of%20Edessa%20%28translator%29">Paul of Edessa</a>, <a href="Paul%20of%20Tella">Paul of Tella</a>, and <a href="Thomas%20of%20Harqel">Thomas of Mabbogh</a>, met with Anastasius at a monastery near Alexandria, as non-Chalcedonians were forbidden from entering the city, and discussions were held to end the schism. Under the auspices of <a href="Nicetas%20%28cousin%20of%20Heraclius%29">Nicetas</a>, governor of Egypt, Paul of Tella and Thomas of Mabbogh represented Athanasius in discussions with the Coptic representatives, and eventually an agreement was reached and the schism between the churches was ended. A joint declaration by Athanasius and Anastasius was issued, condemning the <a href="Council%20of%20Chalcedon">Council of Chalcedon</a> and <a href="Leo%27s%20Tome">Leo's Tome</a>. Afterwards, the delegation remained at the monastery for another month before returning to Syria.
At the conclusion of the <a href="Byzantine%E2%80%93Sasanian%20War%20of%20602%E2%80%93628">Roman-Sasanian war of 602–628</a>, Athanasius sent his "<a href="Synkellos">syncellus</a>" (secretary) <a href="John%20III%20of%20the%20Sedre">John</a> to <a href="Shah">Shah</a>anshah <a href="Ardashir%20III">Ardashir III</a> of the <a href="Sasanian%20Empire">Sasanian Empire</a>, and gave him instructions to afterwards travel to the <a href="Mar%20Mattai%20Monastery">Monastery of Saint Matthew</a> near <a href="Nineveh">Nineveh</a> in <a href="Assyria">Assyria</a> to re-establish the union between the Syriac non-Chalcedonians in the Roman and Sasanian empires. After a synod had been held at the monastery and concluded in favour of the restoration of the union, John returned to Athanasius with the bishops Christopher of the Monastery of Saint Matthew, George of <a href="Sinjar">Sinjar</a>, Daniel of <a href="Duhok">Banuhadra</a>, Gregory of <a href="Dioceses%20of%20the%20Syriac%20Orthodox%20Church%23Iraq">Baremman</a>, and Yardafne of Shahrzoul, and the monks <a href="Marutha%20of%20Tikrit">Marutha</a>, Ith Alaha, and Aha, who were to be ordained bishops to fill vacant dioceses. Athanasius authorised the eastern non-Chalcedonians to ordain their own bishops, and Christopher consecrated the three monks as bishops, and the patriarch then raised Marutha to <a href="metropolitan%20bishop">metropolitan bishop</a> of <a href="Tikrit">Tagrit</a>, with primacy over all bishops in the Sasanian Empire. The eastern delegation returned home, and Athanasius issued a letter to the Monastery of Saint Matthew in 629, confirming its primacy over the monasteries in the Sasanian Empire, and its resident bishop was granted the titles "<a href="Chorbishop">chorepiscopus</a>" and 'head of the abbots', and raised to metropolitan bishop of the bishops of Assyria.
Later life.
According to the "Chronicle" of Michael the Syrian, the Emperor <a href="Heraclius">Heraclius</a> summoned Athanasius to <a href="Manbij">Mabbogh</a> in Syria in 629 to resolve the schism between the <a href="Chalcedonian%20Christianity">Chalcedonian</a> <a href="Greek%20Orthodox%20Church%20of%20Antioch">Imperial Church</a> and the non-Chalcedonian Syriac Orthodox Church. Athanasius and the bishops Thomas of <a href="Palmyra">Palmyra</a>, Basil of <a href="Homs">Emesa</a>, Sergius of ‘Urd, John of <a href="Cyrrhus">Cyrrhus</a>, Thomas of Mabbogh, Daniel of <a href="Harran">Harrin</a>, Isaiah of <a href="Edessa">Edessa</a>, Severus of Qenneshre, Athanasius of <a href="Arabissus">Arabissus</a>, Cosmas of <a href="Epiphania%20%28Cilicia%29">Epiphania</a>, and Severus of Samosata met with the emperor and debated for twelve days. Heraclius demanded they accept a Chalcedonian creed containing the doctrines of <a href="monothelitism">monothelitism</a> and <a href="monoenergism">monoenergism</a>, but this was rejected, and the emperor became enraged and ordered the persecution of non-Chalcedonians within the empire. On the other hand, the "Chronicle" of <a href="Theophanes%20the%20Confessor">Theophanes</a> purports that Athanasius agreed to accept the Chalcedonian creed so to become recognised by the emperor as the patriarch of Antioch, as there had not been a Chalcedonian patriarch since the death of <a href="Anastasius%20II%20of%20Antioch">Anastasius II</a> in 608.
Athanasius died on 28 July 631, and was buried at the Monastery of the Garoumaye.
Works.
The <a href="Syro-Hexaplar%20version">Syro-Hexapla</a>, the Syriac translation of the Old Testament, was written by Paul of Tella on commission from Athanasius in 615–617. Athanasius may have also been the patron of Paul of Edessa's Syriac translation of the "Homilies" of <a href="Gregory%20of%20Nazianzus">Gregory of Nazianzus</a>, as well as the <a href="Harklean%20version">Harklean version</a> of the New Testament by Thomas of Mabbogh.
Athanasius wrote a biography of Patriarch <a href="Severus%20of%20Antioch">Severus of Antioch</a>. The original copy, likely written in <a href="Greek%20language">Greek</a> or Syriac, has been lost, but <a href="Coptic%20language">Coptic</a> fragments survive, as well as an <a href="Arabic">Arabic</a> copy that was later translated into <a href="Ge%CA%BDez">Ethiopic</a>.
